Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 04:42AM - edited Oct 30, 2009 04:46AM by Scoobydoo Hi Ladies. Just popping in from the September 2009 and October 2009 threads to give you a word of encouragement as you begin this chemo journey.  While not fun, you CAN DO this!!! I have been through many SEs but thankfully there are over the counter meds than can help you get through each one.  Make sure you cherish your good days.  My good days normally come after day 7.  I am on a dose dense tx of 4 AC every two weeks and 4 T every two weeks.  I have just completed my last AC tx yesterday.  If there is anyone going on AC...make sure you ask your RN to slow down the cyotoxan to one hour instead of 45 minutes and take either 1000 mg of tylenol or sudafed PE and one 500 mg of tylenol to help combat headache and sinus pressure from the cytoxan. You can bring it with you and ask your nurse if it is okay that you can take it.  I normally take it 30 minutes prior to getting cytoxan. I am the biggest chicken in the world and if I can make it through, then I know you ladies can make it through.  The wait and fear of the unkown is worse than the actual chemo. If you have any questions feel free to pm me if I can help. I will be praying for you. Anita

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2010 08:27AM Scoobydoo wrote: Hey Joan.  The study is SWOG0307 and it is a trial using bisphosphonates.  Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce chances of recurrence of cancer in bone.  Since that is normal progressing of BC is cancer mets in bone.  There are two arms of this study...IV with Zometa and pill with chlodronate.  I have the pill arm and Onty has the IV.  The UK did a study with zometa and found is reduced the recurrence rates of cancer.  The study is closed as of Feb 1st.  However, do you have a trial manager or nurse at your medical center?  You should look into this.  There are many trials that could possibly benefit you.  I am so sorry you had a recurrence.  But you seem to have caught it early which is really good.  And it is good that they had you on chemo.  You are right...you can only make decisions based on the options drs are giving you.  No looking back, no regrets.  Only look forward to the health you are about to experience.  I am surprised though that with grade 3 they didnt have you do chemo. Please keep us updated on how you are doing.  We are all in this together. Anita

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 07:11AM Scoobydoo wrote: Hi Vbabey.  Sorry to hear about hemmies and mouth sores.  I you using biotene?  I use both the toothpaste and mouthwash and havent had a mouth sore yet.  I only took Decadron prior to my first taxol tx.  They gave me benadryl through my port pror to the infusion.  Not sure about Taggamet.  You will do fine tomorrow.  The will give you the taxol slowly to make sure you dont have a reaction.  they will normally have meds available right next to you in case you have a reaction.  I was supposed to get my 2nd tx tomorrow but asked if they could move it to Friday instead.  Oh make sure you have motrin on hand just in case you get bone pain.  I didnt get bone pain until day 3 after infusion.  Onty - I didnt hear that about Abraxane.  Make sure you take your B6 everyday and L glutamine.  It may not make a difference in short term but I hear can make a huge difference over the long term.  Not sure if you will have any bone pain from Abraxane.  Just have meds avail just in case.  Anita

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 01:48PM Scoobydoo wrote: Here is what I found on the syndrome.  If it gets too bad they might have to postpone treatment. However, I am starting to ice my feet and hands as they can help to prevent a recurrence.  One of the lesser-known side effects from chemotherapy is a skin reaction known as hand-foot syndrome, in which the palms of the hands and soles of the feet become red and painful, and the skin may peel, blister, or develop sores. The official name of this condition is palmar-plantar toxicity, though doctors may also call it erythrodysesthesia or erythema. It's much easier to call it by its common name, hand-food syndrome, which is sometimes abbreviated HFS. This condition isn't the same as neuropathy, which is nerve damage (also caused by chemo) and causes tingling, numbness, and a pins-and-needles type of pain. Hand-foot syndrome happens as a reaction to certain chemotherapy drugs. Chemo agents known to cause hand-foot syndrome include: Doctors don't know exactly what causes hand-foot syndrome, but it seems to occur when small blood vessels in the hands and feet break due to pressure or high temperature, allowing chemo drugs to leak into the tissues of the hands and feet. This leads to irritation and inflammation of the tissues.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 02:25AM Scoobydoo wrote: MaryNY - so glad your first tx went well and that the posts here have been helpful to you.  I keep reading and getting helpful tips even though I am halfway through tx.  Vbabey- Glad you are feeling better.  Glad they figured out what was wrong.  Can we have probiotic yogurt whlie on chemo?  What are the benefits?   Onty- thank you so much for your posts and well wishes.  Very few people respond to my posts on the October thread.  Guess because I am new?  Oh well I will keep on posting because it is good for my state of mind and health. Sanaisa - how is everything going?  You had a tx yesterday with me right?  Hope all went well. I have been up since 2am and could not sleep thanks to the steroids.  I cried a little yesterday before starting my AC tx.  I am such a big baby.  I was just so tired of going through the SEs it just got a little overwhelming.  Thank goodness my husband showed up minutes after that episode and was there with me the whole time.  He has been such a rock and help mate through this entire ordeal.  I am so glad that was my last AC!!!!  I hated the cytoxan more than anything.  This time I took sudafed PE and one additional tylenol and that made a huge difference with the sinus pressure.  My RN Onco said that most people say the taxatore is better than the AC in terms of SEs.  I will let you ladies know if that is true. Okay so during my T I will be icing my hands and feet to try to combat neuropathy..I will let you know if that works and I will painting my nails black to stop nails from falling off.  My mom is coming for my first T tx in case I have an allergic reaction.  Oh and it is funny when I go for tx because one of the onco RNs ( a guy) talks to my hubby about sports the entire time we are there.  It like he can not wait until we get there every other Thursday.  It is so funny.  He lights up when we arrive.  Ugh 3 hours of hearing about Redskins and Washington Wizards.  It does make the time fly by. My Onco Dr. has upped my neupogen shots back to 6 since my WBC count dropped so low after she reduced it to 5.  Bummer. I am going to try to get a little nap before family wakes up.  Wish me luck. Anita

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 06:40AM Scoobydoo wrote: Oh this is interesting.  I was diagnosed with hand-foot syndrome from chemo.  Remember when I mentioned last week one of my feet had like a sunburn on the bottom.  Felt like sandpaper when I walked.  Well the RN Onco was very concerned about this.  This was the first I had mentioned it to them.  Seems like this thing can postpone chemo.  It comes when there is leakage from chemo.  My hands and feet are always hot, which creates this situation.  So I will start icing down feet and hands intermiitingly throughout chemo to stop this from recurring. Also have to stay away from hot baths and showers.  Who knew.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 10:39AM - edited Mar 9, 2010 10:40AM by Scoobydoo Mary - I had to buy the kit, which includes several dvds, organizer, bands for exercise and other program information. This program does not provide you food; Sugar and processed carbs (bread) is the issue I have as well.  I dont have the chemo taste in my mouth anymore.  But I do think it takes a long time to get all of the chemo drugs out of our system.  If you want more info on the program google Michael Thurmond six week body makeover.  Jayne-  Your hair is falling out?  That must be hair that was dead that was still in the roots.  I promise you that soon you will see hair.  My hair is coming back in black. However, prior to chemo I had on seen maybe 2 strands of gray. Breast is sore from rads. I am hanging in there.  I am now on day 16 out of 35 rads. Anita
